newsitem.title: BELARUS: Russia's Gazprom cuts supplies to Belarus on debts.
newsitem.headline: Russia's Gazprom cuts supplies to Belarus on debts.

text.p: Russia's Gazprom natural gas monopoly has reduced supplies to Belarus over unpaid bills and threatened to cut deliveries even more, a top energy official said on Tuesday.

"In a telegram to our government, Gazprom said that if no steps were taken to reduce Belarus' energy debt, they would cut supplies by 50 per cent," Nikolai Mochernyuk, president of the state company Beltransgaz, told Reuters.
"If talks between the Belarussian government and Gazprom produce no results, the gas situation could became very dangerous."
Mochernyuk said Belarus's debt to Gazprom was $204 million. Belarus gets 47 million cubic metres of gas daily, but supplies fell by seven million cubic metres on Tuesday.
Mochernyuk said a special "conservation regime" would be introduced in the country starting Wednesday.
Belarus imports 16 billion cubic metres of Russian gas annually.
Monthly oil supplies from Russia have also fallen, from 35,000-40,000 tonnes two months ago to 5,000 tonnes in December.
Belarus owes Russia $50 million for past supplies and annually receives 10 million tonnes of oil for domestic needs and six million tonnes to refine for Russia at its two plants.
